An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
An algebraic closure of a field $K$, denoted as $\bar{K}$, is an algebraically closed field that is algebraic over $K$.

Does the concept of a/an Trivial Algebraic field extension need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic closure of a field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a trivial algebraic field extension is defined as an extension where every element of the larger field $L$ is algebraic over the smaller field $K$. This means that each element of $L$ satisfies some polynomial equation with coefficients in $K$. 

The concept of an algebraic closure of a field $K$, denoted as $ ar{K}$, is a field that is both algebraically closed (no nontrivial polynomial over $ ar{K}$ has unsolvable roots in $ ar{K}$) and algebraic over $K$ (every element in $ ar{K}$ is a root of some nontrivial polynomial with coefficients in $K$).

To define an algebraic closure of a field, it is essential to understand that every element of the closure is algebraic over the original field $K$. This is inherently the definition of a trivial algebraic field extension, where the extension field is entirely composed of elements that are algebraic over the base field. Thus, the concept of a trivial algebraic field extension is implicitly required to define an algebraic closure, as the latter is a special case of the former where the extension field is also algebraically closed.
